「Lìhēi replied: *"Indeed. In ancient times, when Heaven and Earth were formed, the Dao was established with its proper name, and the forms were harmonized to uphold a single principle. It was applied above to Heaven, and extended below to the Four Seas. I have heard that under Heaven there are fixed methods, hence it is said: 'Do not multiply words, for one statement suffices.' Follow the proper name and uphold unity, and the people will not disrupt their principles."*

The Yellow Emperor said: *"Is there still another Way under Heaven?"*
Lìhēi replied: *"Indeed. In ancient times, the August Heaven sent Feng to descend with a single statement that sufficed. The Five Emperors employed it to measure the harmony of Heaven and Earth, to gauge the Four Seas, to embrace the common people, and to rectify the worthies of the age. Thus, slanderous folk all withdrew, virtuous men arose universally, the Five Evils fled, and the age of flattery and sophistry came to an end. Follow the proper name and uphold unity, and the people will not disrupt their principles."*

The Yellow Emperor said: *"When you speak of 'unity,' is it merely unity, or does it also have its length?"*
Lìhēi replied: *"Unity is the root of the Dao—how could it lack its length? What is lost by all, none can uphold unity. The essence of unity is observed in Heaven and Earth; its principle is applied to the Four Seas. How does one know its full extent? Through the near and far, it is measured by never losing unity. With unity, one can govern the myriad; with little, one can know much. When gazing far across the Four Seas, and considering the utmost of high and low, all directions embrace their own Dao. Among myriad words, there is a root; among thousands, there is a key; among tens of thousands, there is a summary. Though myriad things abound, they all pass through a single gateway. He who is not upright yet seizes the ability to govern this—he is not upright. Only the virtuous can wield rectitude to rectify the strange, grasp unity to know the myriad, remove the people’s harms, and maintain what benefits them. Embracing unity and guarding the one, he aligns with the utmost limits of Heaven and Earth, thus understanding their blessings and calamities. Fixed methods that are not constant—Heaven forbids them. Disruptive undertakings—Earth forbids them. Those who lose their commands—sovereigns forbid them. When these three prohibitions are observed, the state is nearly secure. Earth’s prohibitions are: do not drain the high, do not increase the low, do not encroach upon rivers, do not defy the land, do not obstruct the people’s clarity. Advancing without yielding, standing without humility, trampling upon propriety—this is called great misfortune. In human affairs, rigidity and flexibility: rigidity alone is insufficient, and flexibility alone cannot be relied upon. The rigid yet fierce as a tiger perishes; the weak yet drowning in indulgence also perishes. Those who do not uphold ancient laws and proper institutions die; those who monopolize profit and cut short rituals to dwell in luxury are doomed to emptiness. The Dao of Heaven is constant, spread across the lower lands, applied to the Nine Regions. Thus, kings and nobles must be cautious in their commands, so the people know their proper course. Heaven has fixed days; the people follow them naturally. If they deviate, their lives are diminished, and they return to servitude—this is the Dao of Heaven."*

**On Prohibitions**
*"All states that store arms possess military methods. The methods of warfare under Heaven are three: some wage war for profit, some for righteousness, and some for anger. Those who wage war for profit, seeing the people hungry and the state in disarray, with high and low out of place, raise arms to seize them—though they gain no great profit, they also cause no great harm. Those who wage war for righteousness, strike down disorder and suppress tyranny, elevate the virtuous and remove the unworthy—this is called righteousness. The aggressor, though, is the one whom the multitude will slay. Thus, to attack all under Heaven with a single state, or to conquer the world with a thousand-chariot lord—few begin this, and none can complete it, for their resolve is not constant, and they turn back when exhausted. Those who wage war in anger—though their hearts are filled with fury, they cannot merely rage. Anger must have purpose; success must not be sought for its own sake. If they begin with aggression, it is not the Dao. The Dao’s practice is without obstruction. Without obstruction, there is no exhaustion. Hence, the aggressor is doomed, and the prohibitor is the agent of order. Therefore, when advancing, do not linger in place."*

**On the Foundation of Undertakings**
*"The wise act in accordance with Heaven and Earth, align with the people, and bring auspiciousness to spirits and ghosts. They make the people share in benefit, and all rely upon them—this is called righteousness. Their bodies bear the burdens at the forefront; their sovereigns employ them. They bring lasting benefit to the state’s ancestral altars, to the people of the age, and to myriad lineages. When the world’s name is renowned, yet they are not employed, it is in vain. He who gains benefit with a single word is a worthy scholar. He who gains benefit for the state with a single word is a state’s worthy scholar. Thus, the virtuous humble themselves to follow the Dao, use wisdom to discern it, strength to enact it, and cherish its harmony with the age. In times when flexibility is needed to await it, if kings and nobles know this, the state is fortunate. A great state with many people, though its burdens are borne at the rear, is also doomed to misfortune. Hence, the ruler does not rely on fortune to govern the state. To govern the state, there is the Way of the Foreground: to know Heaven’s times above, Earth’s advantages below, and human affairs within. To practice the harmony of yin and yang is to govern; to seize the strange is to bring disorder. Rectified names do not falter; strange names do not stand. The Dao, when upright, is without peril; it can be followed or begun. Thus, one may govern the myriad, one may govern the state. Governing the myriad, one achieves success; governing the state, one achieves peace. Small states gain it to defend their borders; great states gain it to unite and conquer all under Heaven. The Dao has its origin but no end; those who employ it prosper, those who do not merely observe. Following it brings beauty; adhering to it brings constancy. The ancient worthies practiced this Way. Knowing this Way, spirits and ghosts align with them, and so do Earth and Heaven, making them flourish in military and in state. The ancient worthies practiced this Way. The Way of the Foreground—Heaven has fixed days, Earth has fixed constants."*

With the people, share in their labors; with the spirits, share in their rites.
Arrogance and excess lead to strife, while dark schemes bring no auspice.
Severity in governance brings peril akin to death.

To take without giving—such a state shall surely perish.
Near or far, its schemes will rise, and no bone shall stand against them.
Heaven abhors height, Earth abhors vastness, and people abhor harshness.
To grow too high without restraint, Heaven shall cut it down;
To spread too wide without end, Earth shall sever it;
To press too harshly without cease, the people shall rise against it.

When one comes to rule, all eyes turn to behold.
Words must be one, deeds must be one—gain it and never lose it.
Words must be refined, deeds must be harmonious—gain it and never abandon it.

Thus, speech is the seal of the heart, expression its bloom, and qi its manifestation.
To have words without deeds is called deceit.
Therefore, words must precede, deeds must follow.

The straight tree is felled, the upright man is slain.
Without form, without name, it precedes Heaven and Earth—yet remains unformed to this day.

**The Way of Governance**
The Yellow Emperor asked Lièhé:
*"How did the Great Xià (Xītíng) hold sway over all under Heaven?
He did not distinguish yin and yang, nor count the days and months,
Nor mark the four seasons—yet the land was fertile and abundant.
How did he achieve this?"*

Lièhé replied:
*"The Great Xià held sway with tranquility and ease, his gentle measures first established.
He was warm yet modest, humble yet yielding, always yielding yet never first.
His body upright with sincerity and benevolence, his kindness and love for the people profound.
His bearing was dignified yet courageous, never daring to act before others.
He did not seek favor, nor did he cling to singularity.
His conduct was modest, and all he produced was gentle.

He stood firm in what he did not dare, acted only in what he could not avoid.
He demonstrated caution without daring, executed control without presumption.
He guarded weakness, tempered it, and made it firm.
Thus, when the people labored, they did not weary;
when they were hungry, they were not starved;
when they died, they did not grieve.

He did not neglect his people, nor did he lead them to war,
nor did he become the instigator of chaos, nor the mediator of grudges,
nor did he plot in secret, nor make unilateral judgments,
nor scheme to seize another’s lands, nor plunder another’s dwellings.
He carefully observed his people, following Heaven and Earth’s natural course.
He did not act unilaterally, but waited for the exhaustion of rebellious schemes.
When the land was taken by force, or Heaven opposed the time,
he adjusted accordingly and turned adversity to advantage.
Thus, his victories brought no retribution,
his conquests no reversal—
victory abroad brought fortune at home.
His exertions were minimal, yet his renown was great.
This was the ultimate in harmony with the Dao.
This was the Dao of Governance."*

This is the **measure of Earth** and the **modulation of the feminine principle**.

**Sixteen hundred**—the **Dao’s** original constancy,
from the beginning, vast as **Great Emptiness**.
Emptiness unifies as One, constancy abides as One.
**Moist and dreamlike**, yet neither bright nor dark.
**Subtle and pervasive**, **refined and tranquil**—no agitation.

The Ancients had no means to grasp it.
Ten thousand things lacked a standard.
The Ancients had no **form**,
the **Dao** beyond names was **remote**.
**Heaven** could not cover it,
**Earth** could not bear it.
Smallness completes smallness,
greatness completes greatness.
Filling the **Four Seas** within,
yet encompassing what lies beyond.
In **yin**, it does not decay;
in **yang**, it does not wither.
Its **measure** unchanging,
it adapts to **rules** and **patterns**.
Birds obtain it and **fly**,
fish obtain it and **swim**,
beasts obtain it and **run**.
All things obtain it and **live**,
all affairs obtain it and **succeed**.
All people use it,
yet none know its name.
All people employ it,
yet none see its **form**.

**"One"**—its designation.
**"Emptiness"**—its dwelling,
**"Non-action"**—its essence,
**"Harmony"**—its function.

Thus, the **Dao** above is lofty yet undetectable,
profound yet unfathomable.
The **manifest** cannot name it,
the **vast** cannot define its **form**.
It stands alone, unpaired—
no thing can command it.
**Heaven and Earth**, **yin and yang**,
the **Four Seasons**, **Sun and Moon**,
stars, vapors, **rules**, and **patterns**—
all move in **cycles** and **revolutions**,
all depend on the **Root** for life,
yet the **Dao** does not increase their abundance;
all return to it,
yet the **Dao** does not diminish their excess.
**Firm yet yielding**, it cannot be **overcome**,
**soft yet unyielding**, it cannot be **transformed**.
The **subtle** cannot reach it,
the **extreme** cannot surpass it.

Thus, only the **Sage** can perceive its **formlessness**,
can hear its **silence**.
Knowing the **reality of Emptiness**,
only then can one attain **Great Emptiness**.
Thus, the **Sage** unites **Heaven and Earth’s** essence,
harmonizes all without division,
circulates and embraces without excess.

Those who embody this **Dao** are said to be **refined**.
The **enlightened** can discern the **ultimate**,
know what people cannot know,
possess what people cannot attain.
This is called **discerning the extreme** and knowing the **ultimate**.

The **Sage-King** employs this,
and the **world submits**.
Without favor, without malice.
